newsitem.title: USA: Adobe rises on better-than-expected net.
newsitem.headline: Adobe rises on better-than-expected net.

text.p: Adobe Systems Inc's share price jumped as much as 11 percent Wednesday morning after the graphics-editing software company reported fiscal first-quarter earnings that exceeded analysts' expectations.
Shares of Adobe, based in San Jose, Calif., were up four points at 38-7/8 on Nasdaq trade of 3.2 million shares.
After the market closed Tuesday, Adobe said its profits from operations for the quarter, ended February 28, rose 35 percent from a year earlier, to $45.4 million, or $0.61 a share.
Wall Street had expected Adobe to earn $0.51 a share, according to a recent survey by Zacks Investment Research.
First-quarter revenue rose 17 percent to $226.5 million, the company said.
Strong sales of improved products and improved cost control helped boost earnings, said Mike Wallace, an analyst at UBS Securities in New York.
"They're in the middle of upgrading all their major products, as well as good fundamental demand for Photoshop," one of Adobe's key products, Wallace said.

Investors also like that Adobe improved its gross margins -- a measure of profit made from every dollar of product sold -- by three percentage points to 85 percent, a significant improvement, Wallace said.
Adobe writes computer programs that help graphic artists design publications and make illustrations.
Adobe also runs a venture capital operation that invests in Silicon Valley startups. Adobe said yesterday it plans to pay a dividend based on the profit it makes from investments in other companies.
Based on the better-than-expected earnings, at least three Wall Street analysts raised their ratings on Adobe.
